Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 213, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Chelsea District Court under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 213, § 2 and the local rules governing district court venue.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: - Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (discussing landlord duties and remedies arising from breaches of habitability and quiet enjoyment).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses a landlord’s legal duties through adoption and elaboration of an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, specifying what conditions must be maintained and the remedies available to tenants. It details contract-style remedies (rescission, damages, rent withholding, repair-and-deduct, and potential punitive damages) flowing from breaches of that warranty and effectively displaces constructive eviction, thereby also touching on quiet enjoyment concepts. Thus it directly supports a proposition that the case discusses landlord duties and remedies for breaches of habitability and quiet enjoyment.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease… that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. Because we hold that the lease of a residential dwelling creates a contractual relationship between the landlord and tenant, the standard contract remedies of rescission, reformation and damages are available to the tenant when suing for breach of the implied warranty of habitability…. [T]he tenant may withhold future rent, and may also seek damages in the amount of rent previously paid.”
